marks, which have just been made, by two of the. most prominent, able and experienced men of Attakapas, I respond
I,, ilio call which has been made upon me, with unfeigned
diffidence. But when I remember that that call has emanated, principally from my associates, on this floor from St.
Landry ; and that they expect, through me, to make known
to this convention, some of the views of tho particular re-
trion of country they represent, I am emboldened to discharge the duty they thus devolve upon me.
This convention, gentlemen, constitutes an era in the history of, Louisiana. Impressed with the great importance of
developing the resources of our own state, and of enhancing
the prosperity of our own great metropolis ; we have assembled lo confer together, as to the best means of accomplishing these desirable results. The scheme in which we have
embarked, is not merely a local one. It does not seek the
aggrandizement of any particular parish, or region, at the
expense of any other section of the state. It deserves the
sympathy and support of every citizen of Louisiana. As
an evidence that we of the country parishes are alive to the
importance of opening a direct communication between New
Orleans and Southwestern Louisiana, I have but to point to
the numerous and respectable delegations now before me.
And so far as the parish of St. Landry is concerned, I take
great pride in pointing to her representatives on this floor,
who have turned out one hundred strong, to pledge their
parish, its wealth, its energy, its influence, to the completion
ol the New Orleans, Algiers, Attakapas and Opelousas Rail
hoad. Such a body of men never before left that parish at
any one time, or on'any one occasion. Other parishes, though
not so numerously, are ably and efficiently represented. And
it augurs well for the success of our undertaking, that, fired
with enthusiasm, and determined to shake off the trammels
with which they have been fettered, they have met you in
